name: The Chronology of Water
user review:
AFI 2025: film #17
'before i hated him, i loved him'
the older i get, the more trauma i collect, the more grief i experience, the more i find myself haunted. memories slap me in the face out of left field, and one particularly sinister bad dream can ruin my whole day upon waking. the memories stack up in my mind, pushing old ones out to take up space, infecting my cranium like a virus that‚Äôll never shake loose. and no matter how well i'm doing and how happy i am in life, these ghosts live with me now, unpacking their bags and settling down, and every day i adjust to their presence
all that to say, this surprised the fuck out of me. viscerally raw, like cracking open the subconscious like an egg just to see what pours out. the only thing i can think to compare it to cinematically is the work of lynne ramsay, my favorite director, and i don't make that comparison lightly. which definitely helps explain why this worked so well for me: the editing is organically erratic, splicing like it wants to wound. the sound design cracks like a whip, unyielding and intuitive. imogen poots throws down an unbelievable performance, oozing with pure electricity on gritty 16mm, tying the whole thing together with the kind of talent you always hope to find in a movie like this but rarely come across
and my first thought when it ended? that i'm not sure if i can ever watch this again. it's brilliant but deeply unpleasant. i often find no issue in revisiting uncomfortable films, as well as waving away ones that dwell too heavily in the morbidity and lack real worth. but this lays snugly somewhere in between, something i'm so glad i got to experience but need at least some time to digest. might read the book in the meantime. so yeah. super chill film, what a breezy watch
title: The Chronology of Water
plot: An Olympic swimming hopeful flees her abusive home via a Texas scholarship. After losing it to addiction, she studies under Kesey in Oregon. Through writing, family, and self-discovery, she overcomes her troubled past.

name: Disposable Humanity
user review:
superfest 2025: film #10
'if we had been alive today during the war, we wouldn't be here today. then you would not be able to get to know us anymore'
been anticipating catching this doc all year and finally got my chance thanks to superfest, (where it's playing free all weekend on vimeo). i found it often hard to watch but quite informative, i agree with many reviews relating it to something that might appear on PBS, in a complimentary way. on a personal note, i can't remember the last time i cried for such a long time, broken only by the brief pauses i took to dry my eyes and wipe off my glasses. back as a disabled teenager i remember reading dozens of wikipedia articles about T4 and wondering why i hadn't heard more about it, why it wasn't an integral piece of widespread holocaust history. this answers many of those questions and hopefully helps forge a path forward for disabled people as a collective so we can educate, grieve, and strive for better. i definitively recommend this one as a 'must see' film
title: Disposable Humanity
plot: A family investigates the history and memory of the Nazi Aktion T4 program, its targeting of over 300,000 disabled people, and its catalyzation of the Holocaust.

title: Drive
plot: For the better part of the twentieth century to present day, learning how to drive has been a rite of passage for many in western society with eventual automobile ownership considered for some an extension of themselves. With the onset of autonomous vehicles, the skill of driving may become a lost art with some predicting that not only will autonomous vehicles one day dominate the roadways, but that the act of driving may be banned altogether in taking the "dangerous" human element out of the equation. A diverse range of individuals at various stages of their driving life rhapsodize about what driving means to them and their connection to driving and human driven vehicles, and thus their fear of what that loss of being able to drive would mean for themselves and for society.

title: Drive
plot: In an attempt to earn a spot on the LPGA tour, seven women compete in the 'minor league' of women's professional golf - the Futures Tour. Playing in small towns across the country without much fanfare, they travel alone, with fathers, husbands, caddies or friends. They play in heat, humidity, wind, and rain for earnings that rarely cover their expenses. Above all, they play for the love of the game, the rush of competition and the drive to succeed. Their personal stories create a universal portrait of confidence, determination, struggle and patience in pursuing one's dream.

user review: i think for me the biggest issue were the tonal changes throughout, but otherwise i was truly enveloped. marketing it as a rom-com was definitely a mistake, and i think if it loses you at any point it might shatter the whole facade. and i was waiting for it to lose me but it never did, i bought what it was selling from start to finish. reminded me of classic romance dramas touting the shiniest stars in hollywood spitting out vapid truths at each other but still maintaining complete sincerity, sincerity which i feel is rare to sell nowadays, but even rarer that audiences let themselves enjoy it. i really think song is such a strong filmmaker

name: Decalogue I
user review:
giving the almighty dekalog another stab because i've always had a tender spot for kie≈õlowski but am ashamed to say i never finished the whole series
and my god this first entry is jaw dropping. some of his best work, i think, even on its own. i've thought about it quite a lot in the almost 3 years since i first saw it. almost a shame it didn't get its own extended movie like episodes 5 and 6 did with short films about killing/love. and with a heart wrenching ending that probably serves as a good test to see if the rest of the series, and his work at large, is your kind of thing. it is VERY much my thing, so i'm back for more
title: Decalogue
plot: An unemployed man opens a Church to live from the tithes. A teenager sells her body to buy the things her mother cannot buy for her. A young girl, sexually abused by her father, cannot accept he has moved out. A bitter man finds a purpose for his empty life in his best friend's wife. An Eastern European immigrant pushes his wife to work in a strip club to pay his debts. Five interlocked stories offer a provocative vision of the Ten Commandments and how nowadays, many people have to break them in order to survive.

name: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
user review:
genuinely can't remember how long it's been since i've watched this in full, well over a decade according to my diary on this app. it was definitely watched with my dad, i think on dvd, in our living room. maybe my mom joined us, but probably not, it would have been too weird for her taste. i remember loving it instantly but maybe feeling a little too young for it to fully envelop me. it seems like i've lived many lives since that viewing, and have since embraced more than a few charlie kaufman films with open arms, falling in love with his morbid vision of the world. but this rewatch transported me back to beginning, since this was definitely my introduction to his writing, all those years ago on a day i can't even recall
what magic, conjured up and bottled. conceptually it's maybe the most accessible of kaufman's museum of cinematic oddities that i've seen, and emotionally solid to the core, managing to worm its way into the hearts of millions over the years. i thought i might not cry, and then clem starts to fade away, the two of them finally meeting for the first time and saying goodbye all at once. a packed house with many people sniffling loudly after the lights came up, and plenty of people crowding the sink in the women's room using wet paper towels to wipe away tear stains
i think what got to me, to get personal for a moment, is just how much my dreams nowadays blur the lines of reality and memory. having lost my mother a decade ago, and my brother almost a year ago, and more than a few beloved pets in between, i close my eyes every night and sometimes happen upon them, waiting to greet me, or haunt me. they show up, and my mind knows somewhere that they're gone, they're not coming back. that weird ache, that sensation of loss. and sometimes we speak about it, or i ask about it. why are you here? where did you go? how are you back? this isn't right, it's all wrong. memory is the most commonplace ghost on earth, and when memories shape my dreams it can make or break my day when i open my eyes
grief is a part of life and this film beautifully encapsulates grieving those who are still meandering around somewhere, trying not to think of us as we try not to think of them. loss in any form is profound, but it was cathartic for me to revisit such a film with new memories and losses of my own, many lives into the one i've got
i don't want to jinx it, but i've really been falling back in love with movies these days. really hoping i don't fuck it up

name: Stop Making Sense
user review:
rewatched twice in a row and the second time i took notes LMAO. here's what i wrote:
   ‚Ä¢ this is just one gal's opinion, but cutting 'cities' out and leaving 'swamp' in was crazy work
   ‚Ä¢ jerry harrison's shoes look at times like his bare feet and it always takes me out
   ‚Ä¢ during 'burning down the house' i was drumming so hard on my leg with the pen i was holding that it unscrewed without me noticing and flew apart into three pieces 
   ‚Ä¢ all things considered, and this is a tough choice, i think that my favorite performance is 'what a day that was'... so fucking high energy and visually striking with the use of shadows, i get goosebumps bitch. especially the close ups and most especially the shot of lynn and ednah with jerry framed between them on the keys... like COME ONNNNNNN
title: Stop Making Sense
plot: A live performance of the band Talking Heads shot over the course of three nights at Hollywood's Pantages Theater in December of 1983 and featuring their most memorable songs.

name: Nosferatu
user review: rewatched as a part of silents synced which played two radiohead albums during the film, (amnesiac and kid a, in that order). i love stuff like this conceptually and i literally have the amnesiac cover tattooed on my arm, so i secured a ticket for it instantaneously. and what a fun experience!!! really added an interesting layer to a macabre classic. new ways of playing stuff like silent films should be commonplace in repertory cinemas, very cool indeed. kudos to this guy for actually making it happen

name: All the Silence
user review:
seen at the hola mexico film festival
our protagonist, miriam, is well embedded in the local deaf community, raised a CODA and even teaching sign language for work. as she begins to lose her hearing, the grief is tinged with inevitability, her denial only half-hearted as she struggles to join a world she's been adjacent to her entire life
what struck me the most, aside from the singular performance by adriana llabr√©s, is the focus on the relationships in her character's life. the coworker she befriends who has been deaf since birth, his perspective challenging her to see her 'loss of hearing' as something to adapt to, to shift the way she sees life and art. meanwhile, her girlfriend lola is hearing impaired and wears hearing aids, her parents raised her to speak and she never learned sign language. this contrast creates a genuine divide in their relationship, the friction caused by lola's firm belief to try and operate in the able bodied world, seeing herself as 'normal'. when miriam's hearing starts to dissipate, their mutual misunderstanding of each other intensifies and it's heart wrenching to witness
still, seeing her navigate the local intersecting queer and deaf communities, the world a blend of spoken spanish and mexican sign language, a whirl of bodies dancing and laughing, is a truly welcome surprise. i adore how much compassion was clearly poured into this film, making it a highlight for me in recent years. i highly highly recommend checking it out
title: The Silence
plot: When his twin brother Patrick is murdered, Blais travels to the small coastal town where he died to bury him and grieve. But shortly after arriving, a string of similar, brutal, and inexplicable murders occur. With the help of the local sheriff and an enigmatic woman, who claims to have known his brother, Blais unravels a dangerous and terrifying mystery. Our nightmares walk among us.

rewatched it last night, (as i have many nights this week, month, year, all in incomplete ways), rewound the vhs tape, watched it again, rewound it one more time, watched the first half again. late summer is typically a melancholy time for me, the past decade‚Äôs balmy air streaked with grief. this tape has been a recent comfort during my late night loneliness, like a group of friends to keep me company 
it‚Äôs hard to imagine 
that nothing at all
could be so exciting 
could be this much fun

name: Crip Camp: A Disability Revolution
user review:
i was incredibly lucky to find myself this past weekend at the academy museum in LA, rewatching this a few seats away from filmmaker jim leberecht. later when i spoke to him, he asked if i was one of the people he heard laughing so hard during the movie. it was
this remains one of the most impactful films i‚Äôve yet to see in my life. i just turned 30, and most of my days so far i‚Äôve spent isolated from other disabled people, surrounded by able bodied peers, trying to keep up in my wheelchair. trying, and often failing, to match their work ethic, energy levels, social lives. it is a high bar to set for myself, but it‚Äôs all i‚Äôve known
at this event i was overwhelmed by solidarity, hearing disabled creative professionals discuss the industry and how vital it is that we continue to kick the doors down to participate, to be seen, to be heard, to be present both in front of and behind the camera
i‚Äôm so thankful for this movie and for this community. this experience was the exact dream i had in mind when i used to envision my life here. to be a part of something special, even for a day, even for a moment. i‚Äôve said it before and i‚Äôll say it again: this movie is essential viewing. and yes, i‚Äôm talking to you

name: Poor Things
user review:
a cinematic feast. there are a handful of small lulls in the second act, but as a complete picture it devours. the absurdity and tragedy of living boiled down to a rich concentrate and then spray painted all over the walls. i‚Äôm craving that rewatch already
gotta be a career best for emma stone, and i don‚Äôt say that lightly. her character progression is so intuitive that it‚Äôs sometimes almost difficult to watch. human nature captured in facial expressions and body language, the kind of performance that some have attempted but i doubt anyone has pulled off quite like this. and the way the score accompanies her journey, starting with single notes plunking carelessly, eventually finding their footing and growing wilder and more complex with purpose
and i‚Äôm trying to avoid sharing any possible spoilers here because i think going in colder will probably be a richer experience, but i do have to say that the cut from black and white to color is an all timer for me. all things considered, this is probably yorgos‚Äôs most heartwarming and hopeful film to date. what a delicacy

title: Talk to Me
plot: A couple of relationship-challenged people try to find love over a party sex line. Reluctant to reveal her true identity, Betty uses her mother's first name as an introduction to the wonderful-sounding fellow, Arnold. She is shocked that they are able to turn each other on over the phone, and promptly decides that he is the man of her present-day dreams. After some clever detective work (as they had hung up before exchanging phone numbers), she locates him, and they go out on a date. Surprisingly, they don''t click in-the-flesh as they did out-of-the-flesh. She doesn't give up, and subsequently discovers lover-boy has a hang-up with liars. Betty tries to get the advice of Arnold's psychologist brother but, predictably, the revelation of her false name makes Arnold go cuckoo. Meanwhile, Ronnie (Betty's best friend) tests the waters of phone sex, and dates a smoothie who succeeds in seducing her. After being left high and dry, she considers suicide. All in a day's work in the pursuit of love.

name: Sick of Myself
user review:
a satirical stinger, both hilarious and horrific. narcissism dialed up so high that it teeters into munchausen territory. one surprising addition was the layered criticisms of able bodied people seemingly uplifting people with illness/disability, but only if they‚Äôre still outwardly conventionally attractive and profitable to them. when that stops being true their social niceties try to mask clear discomfort as they‚Äôre unsure of what they got themselves into, just as our protagonist, (if you even want to call her that), is unsure as well
i‚Äôve read some reviews wishing that the final act packed a bit more of a punch, and while i understand the let down, i personally disagree. it felt fitting to see a character so privileged and vain doing such unspeakable things in an effort to garner attention from others and it falls flat. and it‚Äôs so interesting to sympathize with her when she‚Äôs suffering, but recoil upon remembering that the suffering is of her own creation. such a twisted experience

title: Babylon
plot: After the insurrection erupted in Libya in the spring of 2012, more than a million people flocked to neighboring Tunisia in search of a safe haven from the escalating violence. When a massive refugee camp was hastily constructed near the Ras Jdir border checkpoint in Tunisia, a trio of filmmakers carried their cameras in and began filming with no agenda. This on-the-fly chronicle of the camp's installation, operation, and dismantling captures a postmodern Babel complete with a multinational population of displaced folk, a regime of humanitarian aid workers, and international media that broadcasts its "image" to the world. Visually stunning and refreshingly undramatic, Babylon reveals a rarely seen aspect of the Arab Spring.

name: De Humani Corporis Fabrica
user review:
AFI 2022: film #4 
‚Äúi need a vacation‚Äù
there‚Äôs some wildly fascinating stuff going on here, but much of it is essentially youtube videos of various surgeries randomly placed around other odd hospital footage. most of the editing choices don‚Äôt feel purposeful and lack human interest to the point of confusion: i don‚Äôt mind cold subject matter, but you can only stare at a close up of internal organs so many times in a row before it feels lackluster. but i did add bonus points for how funny and alarming it was to hear surgeons bickering with each other during a surgery. best laugh of the fest so far

title: Smile
plot: Smile is a drama that follows Jules during the summer after returning home from the lowest point in her life. Clouded by her denial, she must navigate her relationships with her family, her friends, and her future. Jules must decide if she is going to take the steps she needs to save herself, or fall back into a pattern of avoidance and lies. Smile is an exploration of how we respond to trauma through the relationships that shape us, the memories that haunt us, and the choices we make.

plot: A baby, found strapped to a donkey in the North Carolina mountains where her father drowned, is called Twilight and raised by the Anwells. At sixteen, Twilight, in love with her foster brother Jim, who runs the family's lumber business, grows jealous when Elise Charmant, vacationing with her father, a brain specialist, monopolizes Jim at the Fireman's Ball. After Twilight rings the fire alarm to stop the flirtation, she learns that Jim loves her. After the French Canadian lumberman Jules is caught robbing Jim's safe, he slips out of one handcuff and escapes. After he attacks Twilight and falls over a cliff, she becomes deranged thinking that he died. Although Dr. Charmant cannot help her, Twilight recovers when Jules returns after setting the woods on fire. When he attacks her, she shoots him in the leg, but he then handcuffs her to him so that she cannot leave him to die. After Jim carries them until he is exhausted, Twilight drags Jules and Jim to safety.

title: Marry Me
plot: Pretty schoolteacher Hetty Gandy visits a chicken farm and falls in love with John Smith, who soon proposes marriage to her. Before she can give her consent, she is called away, leaving behind an egg inscribed with the date on which she will marry John. The egg is to be given to John for his breakfast, but it goes into cold storage instead. Five years pass, and Hetty waits in vain for John to come and claim her as his bride, meanwhile turning away the proposals of real-estate salesman Norman Frisbie. One day a wire arrives from "John Smith" telling her to be ready to go to an adjoining town with him. The entire town knows of John's coming, and a reception is arranged. When he arrives, Hetty is appalled to find that the John Smith who wired her is not her beloved, but rather a hypochondriac who, believing himself to have become sick from the cold-storage egg on which Hetty had written years earlier, is suing the dealer from whom he purchased it. To avoid embarrassment, Hetty goes with John to a nearby town and, through a series of unlucky circumstances, is forced to spend the night with him in a hotel room. To protect Hetty from scandal, John marries her. They soon come to love each other, and Hetty's love cures John of his hypochondria.

title: Memoria
plot: Memoria seeks to explore and understand the complex historical events of two pivotal years: 1941 and 2022. The narrative is woven from personal testimonies about war and human devastation, yet these difficult subjects are approached through universal experiences and emotions: childhood, family, loss. All the characters have lived or are living through these events as children, sharing profound commonalities.

name: Pleasure
user review:
AFI 2021: film #8
‚Äúit doesn‚Äôt matter what you do for a living, you have bad days at work‚Äù

feels like i‚Äôve been thinking about this daily and singing about it from the rooftops since sundance earlier this year, so of course i leapt at the chance to rewatch. while i still don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs perfect, (and still definitely not for everyone), i‚Äôm glad to discover that it did hold up as a striking film and a fantastic debut for both the director and lead star. i‚Äôm kind of awed by how much plot is tightly wound into the framework, and by the ending it all comes full circle in both bad ways and good. but the perspective might be what i still like the most, every scene that‚Äôs difficult to watch has a purpose and stays firmly planted in the shoes of the lead and is never graphic just for the sake of it. and solidifying my feelings during the q&a was such a nice change of pace after some of the frustrating movie experiences i‚Äôve been having lately. and the soundtrack!!! i could keep saying things blah blah i like movie but basically i think this one is very interesting and relevant and super fucking cool. sk√•l

Local legend, and Valentine's strange behavior spark tales of demonic intervention, blaming The New Jersey Devil, a mysterious demon believed to haunt the Pine Barrens. Locals urge Amber to stay away from the story and the Pine Barrens, but Amber's skepticism leads her deep into The Unknown.

title: The Unknown
plot: Dick Talmadge leads a double life: normally he is the indolent son of Parker Talmadge, the controlling power in the flour market, but sometimes he masquerades as "The Unknown," a masked champion of the people and leader of the fight against high prices. Parker Talmadge and sugar baron J. Malcolm Sweet agree that Dick should marry J. Malcolm's daughter, Sylvia Sweet, but Sylvia disapproves of Dick's worthlessness and considers The Unknown the man of her dreams. A raid on the profiteers' stored goods causes a panic among financiers, who unsuccessfully set detectives on The Unknown's trail, then stage a grand reception as a trap for their populist enemy. The plot fails, but Dick is unmasked in a fight. Sylvia changes her mind about the young man, and all ends happily.

name: Black Widow
user review:
or the one where natasha romanoff finally gets to be a real character (also known as oomf in her pinocchio era)
this is about a decade too late but still managed to entertain me nonetheless, and maybe even more now that i have a year of pandemic and much needed distance from the mcu under my belt. i was never bored (which is rare for me with marvel), and while it doesn‚Äôt feel wholly unique i didn‚Äôt really mind this time around. cate shortland was an interesting choice that i‚Äôve been scratching my head over for years, but the central plot here does tie into her usual focus of free will, childhood trauma and the inner forces of good vs evil. and florence is definitely the standout, her villanelle-esque dry humor and thick accent threatening to leave scarlett in the dust with how easily she commanded the big screen. our beloved may queen is moving up in the world
also, rachel weisz. just had to throw that in here somewhere

name: Fast Five
user review:
WILDLY entertaining and the first movie in the series to truly stand out. a clean heist film with cars going vroom vroom instead of cop shenanigans and needlessly confusing plots. almost every line from vin made me scream and the rock is SO sweaty and SO angry. it‚Äôs clear by this point they finally found their footing and started embracing that slick over the top action while also weaving in the most poignant storyline yet, and as a result i was finally invested. before they were just goofy beefcakes racing cars, but now they‚Äôre a family of goofy beefcakes racing cars. i would even consider recommending this one as a standalone because it‚Äôs so much fun
edit: i CAN‚ÄôT get over the ‚Äúfast‚Äù and ‚Äúfive‚Äù sharing the F in the poster and title sequence. i love it here

name: Margaret
user review:
a grueling but unexpected look at how trauma can inspire extreme waves of selflessness and selfishness. maybe it‚Äôs about this, and many other things too, making clear philosophical arguments while also leaving so much room for interpretation that its trajectory is often skating on the edge of aimless discomfort. a coming of age story so crushingly intimate until it pulls back and reveals how insignificant coming of age actually is. often lisa is the focus of a scene but the sounds happening around her drown her out completely as if she didn‚Äôt matter to begin with
after it ended i realized that in scope it feels like a kaufman film with a more subtle approach to its subject matter by letting the grand ideas speak for themselves (and if they do at all really depends on the viewer). it even suggests a kie≈õlowski influence by intertwining an overall sense of responsibility to the people around us to tread carefully and choose our words more wisely. i vaguely recall putting this on some time in the past decade and not really understanding what it was going for, and now i feel mostly the opposite. neither opinion is really right or wrong because i think they coexist here and in this instance make sense. it feels like it‚Äôs about nothing and everything all at once, and maybe that‚Äôs why i liked it so much
this has one of the most interesting protagonists i‚Äôve seen in a long time. she‚Äôs a lot to stomach, think lady bird but with even less emotional control. in a way it‚Äôs infuriating and the performance can even seem aggressively over the top, but in hindsight this might be anna paquin‚Äôs best role to date and proves how wildly talented she really is. here she plays someone who already doesn‚Äôt know how to truly relate to anyone or show emotion in healthy ways, and then early in the film experiences trauma so quickly and severely that it shapes her whole existence, at least for a little while. she lets her feelings tumble out violently and chooses her words recklessly in nearly every conversation, crying out for emotional support that she won‚Äôt accept and begging for solutions that don‚Äôt exist
if communication is key then this film is an uncrackable lock. being misunderstood is so singularly frustrating, and even more so when grieving or trying to make sense of senseless everyday horrors. the genius of putting a self absorbed (but good hearted) teenager at the center of this moral epic cannot be understated as it puts every moment into perfect perspective, especially in new york city of all places. it suggests that the pain and suffering we‚Äôre experiencing can simultaneously be the most important and least important thing in the world, however dramatic that may seem. we exist inside of our own heads and bodies alone but can‚Äôt forget that everyone else does too. and that‚Äôs one of the great beauties and tragedies of life
so in short: super easygoing film, great for a first date
title: Margaret
plot: Siddartha, a budding entrepreneur marries the woman that his parents chose for him and leads a harmonious life. He gets shattered when he finds that his wife is cheating on him and to take his revenge he invites his wife and lures his boyfriend in an attempt to murder them and commit suicide afterward. The next morning Siddarth wakes up alone at home, with no recollection of what he has done that particular night.

SUPERBAD! but in case that piece of information deters anyone, just know that i thought this was a great great little film and way more substantial than other films i‚Äôve seen by him so far (yes, superbad included, how i love it so). nothing much to complain about here and a lot to enjoy, but worth noting for me is parker posey who i always love but have rarely seen play more of a grounded kind of character. she proves time and time again that no matter the role she‚Äôs just the fucking best
(also, is hope davis the american julie delpy, or is julie delpy the french hope davis? oh it doesn‚Äôt matter, i love them both anyways)

name: Dykes, Camera, Action!
user review: as a film itself this might not be as extensive as it could have been, or even emotionally impactful, but i still got plenty out of it regardless. after almost a decade of reading up on and watching lesbian cinema there weren‚Äôt many surprises for me here but it was so insightful and comforting just to see these women discussing their own films and films they love, films they hate, and just films in general. i could easily watch like 6 more hours of this and i really hope we get more documentaries in the future about the unique and monumental films made by and about people in each group of the lgbt+ community. lesbianism is beautiful and films that reflect it in all its complexity is a really special thing. this is currently on kanopy for anyone interested! (and it‚Äôs a breezy 60 minutes)
title: Dykes, Camera, Action!
plot: A history of queer cinema from the women who made it happen.

name: Undine
user review: casually enchanting in a way that never feels forced, blending a modern love story with a mysterious myth seamlessly by use of visual clues and a gorgeous score. every moment is purposeful and subdued with just the right amount of magic that lingers with me. and this on-screen duo makes my heart ache. i adore this movie
title: Undine
plot: Undine works as a historian lecturing on Berlin's urban development. But when the man she loves leaves her, the ancient myth catches up with her. Undine has to kill the man who betrays her and return to the water.

name: Undine
user review: casually enchanting in a way that never feels forced, blending a modern love story with a mysterious myth seamlessly by use of visual clues and a gorgeous score. every moment is purposeful and subdued with just the right amount of magic that lingers with me. and this on-screen duo makes my heart ache. i adore this movie
title: Undine
plot: The story begins in the realm of Queen Unda, mistress of the under-seas, surrounded by her nymphs, sylphs and mermaids, who disport themselves on the sands and in the waters of the deep. Berthelda, daughter of a fisherman and his devoted wife, has been stolen by the mermaids one day when the child is playing on the sands. Queen Unda rules that little Berthelda shall be left to roam in the Enchanted Forest, because her parents have taken fishes from the ocean, greatly to the annoyance of Unda and Neptune. Undine's mother has committed sin with a mortal and to atone for this her little baby, Undine, is taken to the shore near the fisherman's cottage, to be discovered by the fisherman and his wife. It is Undine's mission on earth to marry a mortal, and thus atone for the sins committed by her mother in loving a handsome young huntsman, whose untimely death likewise robs Undine's mother of her own life. Undine is welcomed by the fisherman and his wife, who consider she has been sent by the gods to take the place of their little Berthelda. Fifteen years pass. Berthelda has been adopted by the Duke and Duchess and among those who pay her court at the Castle is Huldbrand, the bravest of knights. To test his love, Berthelda sends Huldbrand into the Enchanted Forest and bids him return with proof that he had explored its wonders. Coming to the fisherman's cottage, Huldbrand meets Undine, immediately falls in love with her and they are married by a shipwrecked priest, whom Undine has rescued from the sea. Going with his bride to the Castle, there is great rejoicing. At the celebration in honor of Huldbrand's marriage there appears a messenger from Queen Unda who tells Undine her earthly mission is fulfilled and she returns to the waters under the sea. Huldbrand is reconciled to Lady Berthelda and the story ends.

name: Twister
user review: ok i know this was like a blockbuster or whatever when it came out but listen listen... i feel like at this point? in 2021? this is camp. there is something very satisfying about seeing the stormchaser cars drive very fast on a two lane surrounded on either side only by cornfields towards a big huge storm (and this time i actually saw it at the drive-in DURING a moderate medium storm which was essentially a 4D experience). it‚Äôs very high energy and goofy and bill paxton can FEEL the storm and helen hunt NEEDS that tornado to inhale her little funnel sensor warning machine. and they wanna kiss each other so bad but there‚Äôs always another damn tornado!! and honestly besides that? i do not have a single deep thought about this movie. the tornados go woosh and i cheer. and there are so many fucking tornados in this movie, it‚Äôs just so silly and i‚Äôm obsessed. so just hear me out... i think it‚Äôs time for the twister renaissance

title: Nobody
plot: When financier John Rossmore is found murdered in his library, suspicion points to his butler Hedges, who was instrumental in obtaining his divorce. At the trial, when the jury retires, Tom Smith, a young businessman who has sworn he does not know Rossmore, holds out for acquittal and tells his story to the jurors: While he and his wife are vacationing in Palm Beach, Rossmore is attracted to Little Mrs. Smith, and the Smiths are invited on a yachting trip. After Tom is recalled to New York on business, Rossmore drugs Mrs. Smith and seduces her, offering blackmail for her silence. Terror-stricken, she goes to Rossmore's home, enters with a key given her, and shoots him. The jurors agree never to divulge the story, and they acquit the butler.

name: Nomadland
user review:
best picture marathon: film #8
‚Äúbecause she loved rocks‚Äù
this truly feels less like a movie and more like a fond but hazy memory, which might be why it‚Äôs so special in my eyes. life is mostly made up of memories we recount all alone in the quiet, and otherwise we‚Äôre busy distracting ourselves to keep from thinking about them. this honors those memories and gives itself over to a protagonist who chooses to live inside of them while on her journey. always choosing to wear its heart proudly on its sleeve, this is simply a story about people doing their best to get by in a way that also makes them feel happy and free. chlo√© zhao captured and created absolute magic with this one and i think it deserves all the love it‚Äôs receiving
title: Nomadland
plot: A woman in her sixties, after losing everything in the Great Recession, embarks on a journey through the American West, living as a van-dwelling modern-day nomad.

name: Sound of Metal
user review:
best picture marathon: film #7
‚Äúyou saved my life. you made it beautiful‚Äù
i‚Äôve seen many films tackle the subject of change, but never quite like this. the narrative here unfolds more like reality, the lead character riding waves of distress alongside occasional moments of joy and acceptance as he struggles to decide his next move. life is not a straight line, it‚Äôs messy and unpredictable and fucking scary, and this paints that picture in a really balanced way. and it‚Äôs pretty remarkable when a film can center itself firmly on both a character and that character‚Äôs most vital relationship, but this makes it look easy. there‚Äôs a small moment where olivia cooke‚Äôs character stares at the protagonist as he struggles with his new reality, and the pain she feels with him and for him is clear as day. this is such a heart wrenching film, but it also emphasizes finding stillness wherever you are and amidst whatever life is throwing at you. and that is just superb
title: Sound of Metal
plot: During a series of adrenaline-fueled gigs, itinerant punk-metal drummer Ruben begins to experience hearing loss. When a specialist tells him his condition will rapidly worsen, he thinks his music career - and with it his life - is over.

name: Judas and the Black Messiah
user review:
best picture marathon: film #6
‚Äúanywhere there's people, there's power‚Äù
always keeps our focus right where it needs to be and in turn the emotional weight of every scene feels just as heavy as intended. just phenomenal filmmaking with amazing performances all around that never feel overzealous or phoned in. daniel is my personal choice for best supporting (the way he speaks softly to his loved ones is just as impressive as the way he commands a room of hundreds) but lakeith is just as good (lakeith is always good). i do have to say that my favorite performance is still dominique fishback who was absolutely devastating but still perfectly composed from scene to scene (snubbed, snubbed, snuuuuuubbed!). it felt a little long upon rewatch but that might have just been my exhaustion instead of the film‚Äôs pacing. overall this really is a must see
title: Judas and the Black Messiah
plot: Offered a plea deal by the FBI, William O'Neal infiltrates the Illinois chapter of the Black Panther Party to gather intelligence on Chairman Fred Hampton.

name: The Trial of the Chicago 7
user review:
best picture marathon: film #5
‚Äúi‚Äôve never been on trial for my thoughts before‚Äù
the biggest piece of oscar bait in the bunch, but i was expecting that all along. it has its moments of triumph when the music swells and i‚Äôm momentarily won over, but otherwise this is just too much courtroom and isn‚Äôt worth the runtime. sorkin scripts are usually overwhelming at times but this one is especially wordy and feels needlessly distracting, like we get it, you‚Äôre a screenwriter. and he clearly isn‚Äôt the strongest director which makes this uninteresting as a whole. i will say the actors do a pretty impressive job with the material given, but i just know that i‚Äôll be forgetting about this the second the oscars are over
title: The Trial of the Chicago 7

name: Promising Young Woman
user review:
best picture marathon: film #4
‚Äúyou‚Äôre right, ok? is that what you wanna hear?‚Äù
i‚Äôm of the opinion that this is an irresponsible movie. it doesn‚Äôt really matter to me if i think it‚Äôs well made or piss poor, because in the end it just stings with that carelessness. for months i‚Äôve been weighing it on my tongue and mulling it over, and i‚Äôve realized that it only tastes worse every day. and upon rewatch i discovered that i can‚Äôt even accept it as a study of grief or self sabotage in the wake of loss when the ending is just too much to stomach. at one point i thought it would work better as a flat out horror movie, at least then its mixed messages would likely operate better within that genre. but here it‚Äôs just a glitzy mess, too obsessed with drilling the point home that it completely collapses in on itself
it feels like the only intention here is to shame the audience over and over again, and in response to feeling that shame many voters in various spaces have gifted it with a slew of nominations, including at the academy awards. i‚Äôm not really saying it doesn‚Äôt deserve the nominations, (or even the awards), but in a nutshell this feels to me like the most easily digestible ‚Äòme too‚Äô movie yet, more aggressive and well directed than bombshell but with still no real statement to make, both vague and flashy simultaneously so that the final credits rolling are supposed to inspire shock and awe. but it honestly just makes me feel uncomfortable. it tries and has its moments but is overall unable to charm me, and i doubt it ever will as i have no intention of revisiting this any time soon
i‚Äôm gonna end this like i ended my last review of this movie, with recommendations: if you‚Äôd like a 2020 movie that handles this subject matter with more subtle grace then i highly recommend the assistant. or if bloody revenge is more your thing, revenge (2017) is definitely worth a watch. for b-movie horror similar to this i‚Äôd check out american mary. and finally the series i may destroy you, which i haven‚Äôt been brave enough to watch myself yet but have only heard stellar things about and plan to watch soon. i just don‚Äôt recommend this, that much i know for sure, and it really bums me out
title: Promising Young Woman
plot: Nothing in Cassie's life is what it appears to be - she's wickedly smart, tantalizingly cunning, and she's living a secret double life. Now, an unexpected encounter is about to give Cassie a chance to right the wrongs from the past.

to put it plainly: my GOD this is boring. if i had been shown this movie without any prior knowledge, no way would i have been able to guess it was made by david fincher. i‚Äôm not necessarily saying that i dislike seeing a director step out of their comfort zone artistically, but when the end product of that step is this dull... well that‚Äôs another story. i can only recall a few sequences where i really felt captivated, or interested in the slightest, otherwise it always seems to fall short. i‚Äôm glad others are getting something out of this because while i don‚Äôt really dislike it i remain totally perplexed by it. this is simply ‚Äònot my cup of tea‚Äô (and what a bland cup of tea it is)

title: Drive
plot: For the better part of the twentieth century to present day, learning how to drive has been a rite of passage for many in western society with eventual automobile ownership considered for some an extension of themselves. With the onset of autonomous vehicles, the skill of driving may become a lost art with some predicting that not only will autonomous vehicles one day dominate the roadways, but that the act of driving may be banned altogether in taking the "dangerous" human element out of the equation. A diverse range of individuals at various stages of their driving life rhapsodize about what driving means to them and their connection to driving and human driven vehicles, and thus their fear of what that loss of being able to drive would mean for themselves and for society.

title: Drive
plot: In an attempt to earn a spot on the LPGA tour, seven women compete in the 'minor league' of women's professional golf - the Futures Tour. Playing in small towns across the country without much fanfare, they travel alone, with fathers, husbands, caddies or friends. They play in heat, humidity, wind, and rain for earnings that rarely cover their expenses. Above all, they play for the love of the game, the rush of competition and the drive to succeed. Their personal stories create a universal portrait of confidence, determination, struggle and patience in pursuing one's dream.

name: Zack Snyder‚Äôs Justice League
user review:
the interesting thing about snyder is that he always swings big: whether it results in a colossal whiff or a home run just depends on the particular project, amount of creative control, and audience reception. but he always puts his unique style into it, and for that reason i‚Äôve really grown fond of his stuff. his involvement in the dceu has kept me interested, and i still have fun with both their best content or biggest flops. too often nowadays blockbusters, and especially franchise films, fall completely in the middleground and feel a bit too safe creatively, and the effect makes me feel empty and bored. the mcu is guilty of this, and the original cut of justice league suffers as well because of joss being brought in to finish it
comparing the original version to this is like day and night. some of the bones are still here, but the editing has completely changed the DNA: for instance, a heroically cheesy early scene featuring wonder woman and some bad guys has become grim and purposeful here, reminiscent of the dark knight‚Äôs thrilling opening sequence. and with the extra hours allotted there is plenty of time for world building both big and small. more backstories, mythology and villainry are packed in to be sure, but i especially loved that even the side characters get to experience their emotional moments of truth. my favorite aspect of this cut might be the league itself and how the dynamics have changed: the first version relies too heavily on humor and it feels forced, the connections never fully occur and it rings hollow. but here they take each other seriously and grow a camaraderie and respect, at first having trouble getting into the group mindset but eventually working together seamlessly. they look out for each other and work towards a common goal, and when the humor does come out between them it feels organic and earned.
to wrap it up i have to admit that i‚Äôm just happy it exists. this is the justice league i was hoping for before the original came out, and while it‚Äôs still far from perfect it successfully satisfied me and even left me wanting more. it drops the bright and glossy hollywood shine and in turn loses most of the resemblance to its former self, fully morphing into a desaturated snydery melodrama: and i‚Äôm fully on board. it also casts an overall spell in a way that these films usually can‚Äôt quite pull off, both grimly atmospheric and monumental, reminding me more of lord of the rings than any superhero movie i can recall. if you don‚Äôt like superhero stuff, the dceu or snyder i‚Äôd tread lightly, then again you might be surprised. but i love these characters and i‚Äôm glad they got this moment to shine. and personally speaking i think these four hours do a better job than the avengers did with four movies. and cinematically speaking it‚Äôs definitely the winner as well
title: Zack Snyder's Justice League
plot: Determined to ensure that Superman's ultimate sacrifice wasn't in vain, Bruce Wayne recruits a team of metahumans to protect the world from an approaching threat of catastrophic proportions.

name: Pleasure
user review:
SUNDANCE 2021: film #32
‚Äúyou won‚Äôt find anyone like me‚Äù
i‚Äôm completely floored. i‚Äôve been terrified of watching this the entire festival, fearing the worst, and while this is an extremely difficult watch in terms of both sex and sexual assault/violence i never once felt that we weren‚Äôt supposed to have empathy for the protagonist in those situations. sofia kappel (in her first acting role ever) is magnetic and perfectly cast, and behind the camera ninja thyberg masterfully maps out every scene. together they made this intense as wildfire, both beautiful and dangerous, something that i couldn‚Äôt tear my eyes away from even when they began to water and burn
the unflinching look at the sex industry is deeply unsettling but also normalizes it for women in a way that i haven‚Äôt seen properly portrayed in such a film before. it shows situations with high professionalism where consent and respect are key, and then flips the script to address the pressures of being the only woman on a risky set that takes a horrifying turn. the balanced perspective keeps this realistic as we follow the lead from quiet daily routines to glamorous slow motion photoshoots. it explores broad themes like ambition, friendship, trauma and power while also making it clear that the industry has plenty of toxic sexism and racism at its core. the protagonist chooses this path for herself and we witness her contemplative moments of doubt and fear, but she controls her life and chooses it again and again. it isn‚Äôt meant to seem like a mistake or a tragedy but instead a choice. her relationships with the women around her are the most complex and interesting by far, the competition and power struggles providing one of her most intricate hurtles. one of my only problems with the film is the lack of perspective from women of color and/or trans women, this focusing on a white woman who chooses to join the glamorous and famous side of the industry instead of a woman who might have less of a choice or is much more at risk. besides that i can‚Äôt think of much else i would criticize (for now) except for how far it pushes boundaries, but without that i feel in this case like it would lose authenticity and purpose 
the second the film ended i couldn‚Äôt dive into the q&a fast enough, making it the only one of the fest i truly sought out. and watching it only solidified my fascination with the film as the director addresses different aspects of it with a clear perspective. about bella‚Äôs desire to join the sex industry, ninja said she didn‚Äôt want to psychoanalyze the character and try to delve into ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs wrong with her‚Äù, this decision lets the protagonist choose her line of work free of prejudice from the filmmaker (and audience) standpoint. and about the choice of music (which is a mix of opera/hip-hop, all original for the movie i assume because i desperately tried to find the songs afterwards and had no luck), the director compared society viewing women singing opera to be the highest form of art, (with porn being the lowest), and wanted to merge the two, ‚Äúopera is women moaning, but it‚Äôs fine art‚Äù. comments like these gave me more confidence in the film overall, the intentions behind it clearly purposeful and full of agency and respect in regards to sex work while also staying critical about the internal problems within the industry
whew, i had a lot to say about this, but it still feels like i‚Äôm only scratching the surface. this is most definitely not for everyone. it‚Äôs absolutely fucking relentless, but i also found it to be made with a deep level of respect, empathy and intelligence as well. not everyone will feel this way about it, that i already know for sure. this feels to me like a perfect example of an uncomfortable film being rewarding and artistic underneath. i hope it gets picked up so you can choose if you‚Äôd like to see it for yourself

name: Life in a Day 2020
user review:
SUNDANCE 2021: film #24
‚Äúisn‚Äôt that enough?‚Äù
wanted to check this out for the editing and that didn‚Äôt disappoint. for something like this it‚Äôs all about the art of the edit, because good montage editing can convey love, hate, joy, despair and humanity itself, tying themes together to spark emotion. and those sequences did often give me goosebumps, but otherwise i wasn‚Äôt as invested in this or moved by it like some will be. i would love to edit something as ambitious as this one day

name: Land
user review:
SUNDANCE 2021: film #19
‚Äúthank you. thank you‚Äù
we‚Äôve seen this story many times, and yet this still often manages to be a calm exercise in patience, and sometimes momentarily even reaches tranquility. robin is about as good a director here as she is an actor (i‚Äôll let you decide if that‚Äôs a good thing or a bad thing), but even her skills can‚Äôt fully save this from the mundanity of it all. the bond her character makes with a kindhearted hunter is the best aspect of the film, and i will say that the score is a definite highlight for me and one of my favorites of the festival so far. and for all those yearning for a secluded retreat during this past year: here‚Äôs one to live vicariously through. moms everywhere will love this
title: Land

title: Land
plot: Land is the story of a farmer who sells his soul to the devil for power over the weather, resulting in a cosmic battle of elemental human desire. Set at the historic Crossroads in Clarksdale, Mississippi, it is a loving portrait of the filmmaker's hometown. It is a celebration of the marriage of language and love, whose union transforms perception.

name: Mayday
user review:
SUNDANCE 2021: film #18
‚Äúit wasn‚Äôt a very good story. so i‚Äôm giving you a new one‚Äù
this was so frustrating for me. a girlboss daydream in the vein of sucker punch and alice in wonderland, but not as wild as the former and not as dreamy as the latter. the first act was really alluring, the vaguely simplistic world building and lack of explanation works in its favor, but eventually that becomes its downfall. so basically: it totally lacks purpose and ends up feeling pointless. i‚Äôm adding points for the nice atmosphere it offers, the very decent first act, and honestly half a star for mia goth alone because... well... she‚Äôs mia goth. this was her biggest bait yet and she got me hook line and sinker. thanks mia

name: Passing
user review:
SUNDANCE 2021: film #11
‚Äúthings aren‚Äôt always what they seem‚Äù
i was totally convinced that i loved this until it ended and i actually started weighing it properly. it begins so strong but as it becomes more introspective the narrative in turn got a bit lost. that‚Äôs not a bad thing, there are a lot of things worked into the script that work really well as separate pieces and conversations until they start to dissolve together (for better or for worse). the performances are amazing (unsurprisingly), ruth and tessa especially, and the cinematography is exquisite. the ending, however, i‚Äôll have to think on for a while to really figure out how i feel about the movie as a whole. this rating feels accurate while i let it sit, only time will tell

name: Homeroom
user review:
SUNDANCE 2021: film #3
‚Äúat this moment i really don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going to happen. there‚Äôs no way you can cope, you just go on with it‚Äù
a film that rests solely on the shoulders of a group of high school seniors, and they carry it with bold perseverance. the school year begins with high energy and ambition, then slowly morphs into an intimate look at some of the most challenging months in recent years. because of the shift it thankfully feels more organic than other covid-related projects and also focuses a lot on police presence, brutality and the blm movement through the eyes of the students and how they navigate it all. narratively speaking, it‚Äôs a little too wide in scope for me to feel very moved by it, but i was also never bored. this was a pretty solid doc
title: Homeroom
plot: Oakland as a tantalizing case study. In a city that struggles with rising crime and health care woes, its public school systems aren't exactly equipped to prepare youth for the travails of young adulthood.

name: CODA
user review:
SUNDANCE 2021: film #1
‚Äúi‚Äôm happy that you know who you are‚Äù
what a nice way to start this festival: i can‚Äôt imagine a more pleasantly accessible way to frame a film like this. it keeps a down to earth handle on the complex subject matter with respect and self awareness while also maintaining a light touch when it comes to the genre it occupies. it‚Äôs not perfect but was surprisingly comfortable, very warm and funny and enjoyable to watch. and i cried! it‚Äôs definitely cheesy at times but i think it works in this instance, the emotional core is so solid that by the ending it totally won me over. it might also feel too safe for some people (a few scenes felt a little too glee for my taste), and strays a little sometimes when it comes to plot, but i was charmed and would be delighted if mainstream audiences embraced it. upon release i think i would recommend this to almost anyone

name: But I‚Äôm a Cheerleader
user review:
i‚Äôve probably seen the original cut of this movie over a dozen times, and it‚Äôs only gotten better since the first time i stumbled upon it. but for perspective, this review is focused on the new director‚Äôs cut because (and i‚Äôm surprised to say) it kind of rules
the first thing i have to mention is the COLOR: it POPS! the original quality always felt a little lacking and never seemed to be in hd (no surprise considering the time it was made), so this remaster thankfully boasts not just overall quality and sharpness but a beautiful boost in saturation. the pinks and blues are more gorgeous than ever, as are the rest of the colors of the rainbow. i was almost distracted by it in the best way, it feels like the original vision finally coming to light
and about the director‚Äôs cut itself: there are numerous deleted scenes and even a few scene extensions. for the deleted scenes, jamie babbit said she was nervous that people would be bored if it was too long, so she cut scenes that she always loved (including but not limited to a guitar sing-a-long of megan‚Äôs ‚Äúgod is good, god is straight‚Äù cheer, and an informational video welcoming her to true directions. a part of me thinks that was zachary quinto‚Äôs voiceover during that bit?? i could be completely wrong!) and for the extended scenes, the director has spoken a lot before (namely in the documentary this film is not yet rated) about the mpaa initially (and unjustly) slapping an nc-17 rating on the film for a few shots in the sex scene, which i noticed here seems to be back in original form. a lot of various other scenes are extended and with all those small new pieces working together it just feels a lot more complete as a film
so with that i really recommend checking out this version, even if you‚Äôre seeing this movie for the first time. i‚Äôm a big fan of the original but this just made it even more enjoyable for me, which is something i didn‚Äôt see coming considering how minor the changes seem in scope. it‚Äôs definitely one of the only films that continues to grow on me with time, and this only helped with that
title: But I'm a Cheerleader
plot: A naive teenager is sent to rehab camp when her straitlaced parents and friends suspect her of being a lesbian.

name: Promising Young Woman
user review:
the outer layer is a bright candy coated shell, but peeling that back reveals the inside as hollow. i don‚Äôt have negative feelings about the ending (or the film as a whole) the way some do, actually i enjoyed it until it was almost over. but then the bad taste it left behind immediately started creeping in. as a complete picture it just feels like a bunch of gotcha moments that lack a certain kind of empathy for the subject matter. the ending solidified my problems with it, bringing such potential together for just another bigger gotcha moment. it‚Äôs bold, and i dig that, but surely justice can be doled out with a little hope still attached. without that hope it just feels too cruel for my liking
all that being said, carey mulligan was so solid here, she never gives a bad performance. and i‚Äôll throw this in just because it‚Äôs on my mind: the assistant, which came out this year as well, feels to me like the antithesis of this (and of something like bombshell) in the best way. i highly recommend it for a different approach to this kind of story

name: Run
user review:
in today‚Äôs world this feels like a familiar story, echoing both fiction like sharp objects and real stories like gypsy rose blanchard, but that familiarity doesn‚Äôt make it any less potent here. i was skeptical, not wanting to indulge this worn out plot that seemingly exists only to mystify and thrill able bodied audiences. but i‚Äôm excited to say that‚Äôs not exactly what i found in this case
my first discovery here was that newcomer kiera allen acts circles around sarah paulson. the latter is clearly the selling point, her name all over the advertising in big bold letters, ‚Äúlook at sarah paulson go, look at her cry, look at her scream‚Äù, fleshing out the kind of sadistic and melodramatic role that she‚Äôs best at. but seeing a real wheelchair user maneuver nightmare scenarios and experience all levels of terror was something i‚Äôve never really experienced before. and i‚Äôm not gonna lie, it makes all the difference for me. this isn‚Äôt just joey king wearing big glasses, or kevin mchale climbing out of his prop wheelchair in a dream sequence to dance. this is someone that pushes off walls with her arms in tight spaces and rounds sharp corners on a dime. does being disabled make her a good actor? of course not, but the good news is that she is a good actor. the whole movie rests solely on kiera allen‚Äôs shoulders, and she carries it boldly and independently while sarah pounds on the door outside
i don‚Äôt talk about my disability all that often in online spaces, only truly out of habit because these online spaces have been my biggest escape from the limitations that come with being disabled in the real world. but seeing fragments of yourself represented on screen when you so rarely are is a powerful feeling, like gasping for air when you didn‚Äôt realize you were being held underwater. on it‚Äôs own, this film is a thrilling enough ride, aptly made and successfully placing us in the shoes of the main character, fearing sarah paulson like we‚Äôre so used to doing. but the choices made with casting (and small specifics in things like writing and set design) changed the overall feeling for myself and possibly for others like me who relate to these particular struggles. for able bodied audiences they might as well be watching a slasher film, or any b-movie thriller. but every day i face small obstacles like some of the ones shown here: a staircase laid out in front of me as if to taunt me, or a set of front wheels buried deep in mud. can‚Äôt get out of a car unless the person i‚Äôm with gets my chair out for me, and even in the best scenarios that can still feel crushingly isolating and even momentarily scary at times
does a part of me wish the story here was a bit different? of course i do. but there‚Äôs something to be said for small change happening slowly with stories that we‚Äôre already well aquatinted with. yes, on the surface this is just a mother-daughter thriller, but the brilliant performance by a disabled actor makes it shine. and yes, a movie like the upcoming happiest season is just a safe holiday rom-com, but the lgbt representation might make all the difference for a community that has never seen itself in that beloved and comforting sub-genre, just like i‚Äôd never seen a real life disabled final girl until tonight, and didn‚Äôt even realize how much i wanted to. not everything has to be a grand movement, a monumental shift that shakes us to our core with bold statements and unique outlooks, no matter how much we desire that as soon as we can get it (or create it ourselves). small steps leave a softer but lasting impression, something that might not make waves with its originality but will quietly stick with those who relate to it. and some people can mock cries for representation in media if they like, but the reality is that until we‚Äôre all able to see ourselves on screen (and behind it) we won‚Äôt all be able to fully grasp the real power of visual storytelling and what a welcoming relief it is to be able to relate to it
title: Run
plot: Jerome becomes a street cop in hopes to find the killer of his mother, while also trying to find the identity of himself through love. He later on finds out, not only did his mother neglect him but kept secrets.

title: Run
plot: Run escapes... He just killed the Prime Minister of his country. In order to do so, he had to act as if he was a crazy man, wandering through the city. His life comes back by flashes ; his childhood with Tourou when his dream was to become a rain miracle-worker, his adventures with Gladys the eater, and his past as a young member of militia, in the heart of the politic and military conflict in Ivory Coast. All those lives, Run didn't choose them. Everytime, he felt in by running from another life. That's the reason why his name's Run.

does a part of me wish the story here was a bit different? of course i do. but there‚Äôs something to be said for small change happening slowly with stories that we‚Äôre already well aquatinted with. yes, on the surface this is just a mother-daughter thriller, but the brilliant performance by a disabled actor makes it shine. and yes, a movie like the upcoming happiest season is just a safe holiday rom-com, but the lgbt representation might make all the difference for a community that has never seen itself in that beloved and comforting sub-genre, just like i‚Äôd never seen a real life disabled final girl until tonight, and didn‚Äôt even realize how much i wanted to. not everything has to be a grand movement, a monumental shift that shakes us to our core with bold statements and unique outlooks, no matter how much we desire that as soon as we can get it (or create it ourselves). small steps leave a softer but lasting impression, something that might not make waves with its originality but will quietly stick with those who relate to it. and some people can mock cries for representation in media if they like, but the reality is that until we‚Äôre all able to see ourselves on screen (and behind it) we won‚Äôt all be able to fully grasp the real power of visual storytelling and what a welcoming relief it is to be able to relate to it

my first discovery here was that newcomer kiera allen acts circles around sarah paulson. the latter is clearly the selling point, her name all over the advertising in big bold letters, ‚Äúlook at sarah paulson go, look at her cry, look at her scream‚Äù, fleshing out the kind of sadistic and melodramatic role that she‚Äôs best at. but seeing a real wheelchair user maneuver nightmare scenarios and experience all levels of terror was something i‚Äôve never really experienced before. and i‚Äôm not gonna lie, it makes all the difference for me. this isn‚Äôt just joey king wearing big glasses, or kevin mchale climbing out of his prop wheelchair in a dream sequence to dance. this is someone that pushes off walls with her arms in tight spaces and rounds sharp corners on a dime. does being disabled make her a good actor? of course not, but the good news is that she is a good actor. the whole movie rests solely on kiera allen‚Äôs shoulders, and she carries it boldly and independently while sarah pounds on the door outside
i don‚Äôt talk about my disability all that often in online spaces, only truly out of habit because these online spaces have been my biggest escape from the limitations that come with being disabled in the real world. but seeing fragments of yourself represented on screen when you so rarely are is a powerful feeling, like gasping for air when you didn‚Äôt realize you were being held underwater. on it‚Äôs own, this film is a thrilling enough ride, aptly made and successfully placing us in the shoes of the main character, fearing sarah paulson like we‚Äôre so used to doing. but the choices made with casting (and small specifics in things like writing and set design) changed the overall feeling for myself and possibly for others like me who relate to these particular struggles. for able bodied audiences they might as well be watching a slasher film, or any b-movie thriller. but every day i face small obstacles like some of the ones shown here: a staircase laid out in front of me as if to taunt me, or a set of front wheels buried deep in mud. can‚Äôt get out of a car unless the person i‚Äôm with gets my chair out for me, and even in the best scenarios that can still feel crushingly isolating and even momentarily scary at times
does a part of me wish the story here was a bit different? of course i do. but there‚Äôs something to be said for small change happening slowly with stories that we‚Äôre already well aquatinted with. yes, on the surface this is just a mother-daughter thriller, but the brilliant performance by a disabled actor makes it shine. and yes, a movie like the upcoming happiest season is just a safe holiday rom-com, but the lgbt representation might make all the difference for a community that has never seen itself in that beloved and comforting sub-genre, just like i‚Äôd never seen a real life disabled final girl until tonight, and didn‚Äôt even realize how much i wanted to. not everything has to be a grand movement, a monumental shift that shakes us to our core with bold statements and unique outlooks, no matter how much we desire that as soon as we can get it (or create it ourselves). small steps leave a softer but lasting impression, something that might not make waves with its originality but will quietly stick with those who relate to it. and some people can mock cries for representation in media if they like, but the reality is that until we‚Äôre all able to see ourselves on screen (and behind it) we won‚Äôt all be able to fully grasp the real power of visual storytelling and what a welcoming relief it is to be able to relate to it

title: Run
plot: JACQUELIN, an uptight middle class French lady (Kayla Eva), joins a dating site in search of the perfect novel-like romance and adventure she's always imagined, she connects with BAYO (Ramsey Nouah), a self-made young, rich lawyer in far away West Africa who has a seemingly boring life. In a few weeks she finds herself in Nigeria to meet the man behind the computer screen. The story takes a twist when Jacquelin was kidnapped and becomes a victim of mistaken identity.

title: Run, Broken Yet Brave
plot: RUN, is the story of Ashley, a sixteen-year old teenager with a chip on her shoulder. She is sent by her mom to spend a month of her summer holidays with her grandparents on the family farm. While there she develops a love-hate relationship with her grandfather Joseph, a full- blooded Cree Indian who stresses rules and respect. Slowly her grandfather introduces her to traditions he learned on the reserve as a boy. All seems well until Ashley finds a picture album from the attic and begins asking questions, questions that reveal a secret that threatens to tear the family apart. In the end the story is about redemptive love and the power of forgiveness woven into the traditions of First Nations culture.

in today‚Äôs world this feels like a familiar story, echoing both fiction like sharp objects and real stories like gypsy rose blanchard, but that familiarity doesn‚Äôt make it any less potent here. i was skeptical, not wanting to indulge this worn out plot that seemingly exists only to mystify and thrill able bodied audiences. but i‚Äôm excited to say that‚Äôs not exactly what i found in this case
my first discovery here was that newcomer kiera allen acts circles around sarah paulson. the latter is clearly the selling point, her name all over the advertising in big bold letters, ‚Äúlook at sarah paulson go, look at her cry, look at her scream‚Äù, fleshing out the kind of sadistic and melodramatic role that she‚Äôs best at. but seeing a real wheelchair user maneuver nightmare scenarios and experience all levels of terror was something i‚Äôve never really experienced before. and i‚Äôm not gonna lie, it makes all the difference for me. this isn‚Äôt just joey king wearing big glasses, or kevin mchale climbing out of his prop wheelchair in a dream sequence to dance. this is someone that pushes off walls with her arms in tight spaces and rounds sharp corners on a dime. does being disabled make her a good actor? of course not, but the good news is that she is a good actor. the whole movie rests solely on kiera allen‚Äôs shoulders, and she carries it boldly and independently while sarah pounds on the door outside
i don‚Äôt talk about my disability all that often in online spaces, only truly out of habit because these online spaces have been my biggest escape from the limitations that come with being disabled in the real world. but seeing fragments of yourself represented on screen when you so rarely are is a powerful feeling, like gasping for air when you didn‚Äôt realize you were being held underwater. on it‚Äôs own, this film is a thrilling enough ride, aptly made and successfully placing us in the shoes of the main character, fearing sarah paulson like we‚Äôre so used to doing. but the choices made with casting (and small specifics in things like writing and set design) changed the overall feeling for myself and possibly for others like me who relate to these particular struggles. for able bodied audiences they might as well be watching a slasher film, or any b-movie thriller. but every day i face small obstacles like some of the ones shown here: a staircase laid out in front of me as if to taunt me, or a set of front wheels buried deep in mud. can‚Äôt get out of a car unless the person i‚Äôm with gets my chair out for me, and even in the best scenarios that can still feel crushingly isolating and even momentarily scary at times
does a part of me wish the story here was a bit different? of course i do. but there‚Äôs something to be said for small change happening slowly with stories that we‚Äôre already well aquatinted with. yes, on the surface this is just a mother-daughter thriller, but the brilliant performance by a disabled actor makes it shine. and yes, a movie like the upcoming happiest season is just a safe holiday rom-com, but the lgbt representation might make all the difference for a community that has never seen itself in that beloved and comforting sub-genre, just like i‚Äôd never seen a real life disabled final girl until tonight, and didn‚Äôt even realize how much i wanted to. not everything has to be a grand movement, a monumental shift that shakes us to our core with bold statements and unique outlooks, no matter how much we desire that as soon as we can get it (or create it ourselves). small steps leave a softer but lasting impression, something that might not make waves with its originality but will quietly stick with those who relate to it. and some people can mock cries for representation in media if they like, but the reality is that until we‚Äôre all able to see ourselves on screen (and behind it) we won‚Äôt all be able to fully grasp the real power of visual storytelling and what a welcoming relief it is to be able to relate to it
title: Run
plot: Jaxon Reeves is a hunted man. His wife has been taken. Now members of a secret government agency want to secure a disk that may contain plans of an alien invasion. With the Men in Black closing in, Jax has no choice but to run.

my first discovery here was that newcomer kiera allen acts circles around sarah paulson. the latter is clearly the selling point, her name all over the advertising in big bold letters, ‚Äúlook at sarah paulson go, look at her cry, look at her scream‚Äù, fleshing out the kind of sadistic and melodramatic role that she‚Äôs best at. but seeing a real wheelchair user maneuver nightmare scenarios and experience all levels of terror was something i‚Äôve never really experienced before. and i‚Äôm not gonna lie, it makes all the difference for me. this isn‚Äôt just joey king wearing big glasses, or kevin mchale climbing out of his prop wheelchair in a dream sequence to dance. this is someone that pushes off walls with her arms in tight spaces and rounds sharp corners on a dime. does being disabled make her a good actor? of course not, but the good news is that she is a good actor. the whole movie rests solely on kiera allen‚Äôs shoulders, and she carries it boldly and independently while sarah pounds on the door outside
i don‚Äôt talk about my disability all that often in online spaces, only truly out of habit because these online spaces have been my biggest escape from the limitations that come with being disabled in the real world. but seeing fragments of yourself represented on screen when you so rarely are is a powerful feeling, like gasping for air when you didn‚Äôt realize you were being held underwater. on it‚Äôs own, this film is a thrilling enough ride, aptly made and successfully placing us in the shoes of the main character, fearing sarah paulson like we‚Äôre so used to doing. but the choices made with casting (and small specifics in things like writing and set design) changed the overall feeling for myself and possibly for others like me who relate to these particular struggles. for able bodied audiences they might as well be watching a slasher film, or any b-movie thriller. but every day i face small obstacles like some of the ones shown here: a staircase laid out in front of me as if to taunt me, or a set of front wheels buried deep in mud. can‚Äôt get out of a car unless the person i‚Äôm with gets my chair out for me, and even in the best scenarios that can still feel crushingly isolating and even momentarily scary at times
does a part of me wish the story here was a bit different? of course i do. but there‚Äôs something to be said for small change happening slowly with stories that we‚Äôre already well aquatinted with. yes, on the surface this is just a mother-daughter thriller, but the brilliant performance by a disabled actor makes it shine. and yes, a movie like the upcoming happiest season is just a safe holiday rom-com, but the lgbt representation might make all the difference for a community that has never seen itself in that beloved and comforting sub-genre, just like i‚Äôd never seen a real life disabled final girl until tonight, and didn‚Äôt even realize how much i wanted to. not everything has to be a grand movement, a monumental shift that shakes us to our core with bold statements and unique outlooks, no matter how much we desire that as soon as we can get it (or create it ourselves). small steps leave a softer but lasting impression, something that might not make waves with its originality but will quietly stick with those who relate to it. and some people can mock cries for representation in media if they like, but the reality is that until we‚Äôre all able to see ourselves on screen (and behind it) we won‚Äôt all be able to fully grasp the real power of visual storytelling and what a welcoming relief it is to be able to relate to it

title: Run
plot: A gifted track runner, is preparing herself for her upcoming competition by running around the outskirts of her town. Which is when she comes across a very unusual and gruesome discovery, a dead body infested with bugs in the middle of the woods. The previous victim of a cold-blooded serial killer taking refuge in the area, looking for his next victim. After this terrifying discovery, the gifted track runner attracts unwanted attention right before her upcoming competition. Will she be able to run from this merciless murderer? Or will she end up hidden in a forest as his next victim?
